study_info.title: A 6-Base Pair In-Frame Germline Deletion in Exon 7 of RET Leads to Increased RET Phosphorylation, ERK Activation, and MEN2A
study_info.study_focus: Novel RET exon 7 in-frame deletion (p.505_506del) causing MEN2A

variant_info.domain: End of cadherin-like domain, upstream of cysteine-rich region

evidence.database: Not in COSMIC, not in Utah MEN2 database, not found in 135 healthy controls

patient_data.postoperative_status: Complete remission (plasma metanephrines and calcitonin undetectable)

functional_data.autophosphorylation: Increased ligand-independent Tyr905 phosphorylation (stronger than WT, less than C634R)
functional_data.erk_activation: Strong activation (significant luciferase increase vs WT; less than C634R)
functional_data.akt_activation: Increased phosphorylation compared to WT; less than C634R
functional_data.colony_formation: 4× WT RET (similar to C634R); statistically significant
functional_data.dimerization: Absent for p.505_506del; present for C634R

comparisons.vs_wt: All functional effects stronger than WT RET
comparisons.vs_c634r: Weaker MAPK/ERK/AKT activation than C634R, but similar increased colony formation; no dimerization in deletion mutant

clinical_patterns.phenotype: Bilateral pheochromocytoma at 31 years, MTC at 37 years (atypical timeline for MEN2A)
clinical_patterns.disease_course: Pheo→MTC sequence, similar to V292M (exon 5) RET mutations
clinical_patterns.mutation_novelty: First reported activating deletion in RET exon 7; not in major mutation databases
exon_screening_issues: Missed by routine RET exon 10/11/13 analysis
Exon 7 not commonly sequenced in clinical practice

discussion_notes: Routine RET screening misses rare/non-hotspot mutations; exon 7 not typically analyzed.
Novelty: First MEN2A-causing mutation described in RET exon 7.
Strict clinical/genetic diagnosis needed full-coding RET sequencing.
Phenotype resembles V292M (codon 292, exon 5) with early pheo and late MTC.
Supports full RET sequencing (not just hotspot exons) in MEN2-suspect cases.
No family history and no mutation in parents/sibling confirms de novo status.
Molecular mechanism: No dimerization (unlike cysteine mutations); likely conformational effect activating kinase domain.
Mutation not detected in >135 controls or known disease/variant databases.
Clinical: Milder gain-of-function than C634R (canonical MEN2A); clinical course still justifies pathogenicity classification.
Remission after surgery; no further MTC/pheo or parathyroid abnormalities.
Whole-exome or Sanger sequencing of non-hotspot exons should be considered when clinical suspicion persists and initial screening is negative.
Implications for broader genetic screening strategies in hereditary pheochromocytoma/MTC syndromes.
